items.message: This flood alert remains in place. Areas most at risk include low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. items.message: River levels downstream on the River Yeo, and on the Rivers Cam and Wriggle, have fallen but the level remains high at Sherborne Lake, which is still above the Alert level. A band of heavy persistent rain is forecast from this evening, Monday 08 December 2025, through to about midday tomorrow, which will cause flooding impacts and sustain this Alert. Other rivers in the area, including the Rivers Yeo, Cam and Wriggle, are forecast to rise. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is is likely in this area, including around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.  We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. We are checking defences and clearing bridges, culverts and screens where necessary. Continue to take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Keep checking for updates to these Alerts. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: Tide locking where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea,  this afternoon may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 12:30pm to 2:30pm today, Tuesday 9th December. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. River levels may remain high over the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 10th December 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The Yeo and Parrett rivers are still high, sustained by the high flows following the weekend's rain. A band of heavy persistent rain is forecast from this evening, Monday 08/12/2025, through to about midday tomorrow, which will cause further flooding impacts and sustain this Alert. The rain will cause rivers to rise again and bring fresh flows down into the Moors. Drier weather is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday. The current river level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.14m and falling. The current drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 6.99m and falling slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3m; the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m; the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Drayton above 8.8m. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. We are pumping when river levels allow. Avoid driving through flood water. Refer to the local authority website for any local road closures. This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are starting to fall.  Further rainfall is forecast for the afternoon of 09/12/2025 and into Wednesday 10/12/2025.  This flood alert will remain out as rivers are expected  to rise in response to the rainfall. 

Flooding is possible in the evening of 09/12/2025 and into 10/12/2025.  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Brue, River Sheppey, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road.  Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely.  Areas most at risk include the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road.  Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  
Start actioning your flood plan if you have one. We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  This message will be updated by 1 pm on 10/12/2025.

The Cuckmere River is rising following Tuesday morning's rain. From 14:00 09/12/2025 minor flood impacts could affect fields near Station Road and Church Road, Hellingly. From 19:00 09/12/2025 minimal flood impacts could affect fields near North Street and River Lane, Alfriston. Showers are possible Tuesday afternoon, but very little rain is forecast over the next five days. River levels should begin to fall by 20:00 09/12/2025 in Hellingly, and by 08:00 10/12/2025 in Alfriston. River levels are expected to peak a little lower than they were in recent days, and return nearer to a normal level by Thursday. We are  closely monitoring the situation. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood (Mill Ln Church Rd Hellingly, North St Alfriston). This message will be updated by 14:00 10/12/2025.

Showers are possible Tuesday afternoon, but very little rain is forecast over the next five days. River levels should begin to fall near Selham by 04:00 10/12/2025, and by 16:00 10/12/2025 in Fittleworth. River levels will probably peak a little higher than last weekend. Returning nearer to a normal level by Thursday in most locations, but not until next week in Fittleworth. River levels have already peaked in Liss, and will peak around 17:00 09/12/2025 in Iping, with only minimal flood impacts.  We are  closely monitoring the situation. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. This message will be updated by 14:00 10/12/2025.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and consider acting on your flood plan if you have one.  This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

Forecast rising river levels tomorrow may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 09 December 2025 due to heavy rainfall this evening and overnight. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne.  Flooding is possible from Tuesday morning as river levels are expected to rise after forecast intense rainfall this evening, overnight and throughout Tuesday.  Weather conditions are expected to improve from Wednesday with little rainfall expected. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and monitor local water levels and weather conditions. 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels have fallen on most rivers in West Somerset, but remain high on the Washford River, which is still above the Flood Alert level. A band of heavy persistent rain is forecast from this evening, Monday 08 December 2025, through to about midday tomorrow, which will cause flooding impacts and sustain this Alert. The Washford River, and other rivers in the area. are forecast to rise. Flooding is possible on low lying land and roads near the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Drier weather is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. We are checking defences and clearing bridges, culverts and screens where necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Keep checking for updates to these Alerts. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 09 December 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 4:30 PM to 6:30 PM on 09/12/2025. 
The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.63mAOD at 5:30 PM on 09/12/2025.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. Flooding of properties is not expected.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is 120 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to rise for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide on Tuesday morning. 
Areas particularly at risk include roads along the seafronts.

The high tide at Plymouth on Tuesday morning is at 08:30, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 2.81mAOD, which is 0.58 metres above tide table level.  Strong force 8 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 5m are forecast over the high tide.
Coastal conditions should ease for Tuesday evening's high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
Higher than normal tides may lead to flooding over the next few days. 

Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness over the coming days. Some lengths of the flood embankment at Longney and The Noards may be overtopped. Rodley Lane, Westbury and Awre Road, Brims Pill may be flooded.  

Predicted peaks: - 

Wednesday morning 10/12; Gloucester 2.9m to 3.2m at 01:00AM, Sandhurst 3.5m to 3.7m at 01:30AM 
Wednesday afternoon 10/12; Gloucester 2.9m to 3.2m at 13:30PM, Sandhurst 3.6m to 3.7m at 13:45PM. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions.  

This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 10 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone at Currymoor Pumping Station is still high.  Further rainfall is forecast for the afternoon of 09/12/2025 and into Wednesday 10/12/2025.  This flood alert will remain out as rivers are expected  to rise in response to the rainfal.. The rain will cause rivers to rise again and bring fresh flows down into the Moors. Drier weather is forecast on Wednesday until Thursday evening. The current River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.45m and is steady. Water enters Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The current drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 4.80m and rising steadily. Cutts Road floods if this level is above 5.75m, and New Road floods if it is above 6.18m. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. We are pumping when river levels allow. Take care and avoid driving through flood water. Refer to the local authority website for any local road closures. This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 10 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.

Townfield Lane is now impassable. Flood Warnings are not currently expected to be issued.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 10 December 2025, or as the situation changes.

Bewdley 2.9m to 3.2m Friday morning, 12/12/25. 
Worcester 3.5 to 4.0m Friday evening, 12/12/25. 
Diglis 3.1m to 3.6m Friday evening, 12/12/25.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 09 December 2025 from 12:15 due to high tide levels and high flows. 
Flooding could affect the area for 1.5 hours either side of high water, the incoming tide will prevent river from flowing to sea. The tide is at 13:46 and at 16:06 on 09/12/2025. Storm Bram increases tide table values by 0.57m. Total forecast tide is 5.01m Chart Datum (2.27 mAOD). Strong South Westerly Force 7 wind. River flows in the River Itchen are high due to the overnight rainfall. This may flood the access road and the car park near to the White Swan Pub at Mansbridge. Footpath flooding may affect Riverside Park. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 17:30 on 09/12/2025. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have , including defences around the White Swan pub. 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 10 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Tuesday afternoon's tide at 14:00 on 09/12/2025. 
Storm Bram increases tide table values by 0.57 m. Total forecast tide is 4.68 metres Chart Datum (2.09 mAOD) at Cowes. Strong South Westerly Force 7 wind. Large waves will cause spray overtopping and overwashing of defences across the exposed coast at Yarmouth, Freshwater Bay, Sandown, Shanklin, Gurnard and Ryde. This will flood esplanades, sea front car parks and roads in these locations. As Cowes is sheltered from waves, impacts, if any, will be minimal. We do not expect property flooding. Wednesday's tide at 03:03 on 10/12/2025 is forecast to be 54 cm lower (1.55 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide on Tuesday morning. 
Areas particularly at risk include roads along the seafronts.

The high tide at Exmouth on Tuesday morning is at 09:30, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 2.5mAOD, which is 0.61 metres above tide table level.  Strong force 7 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast over the high tide.

Coastal conditions should ease for Tuesday evening's high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 1:00PM on 9/12/2025 to 5:00PM on 9/12/2025. 
Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates where necessary. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Tuesday's early morning tide and early afternoon tide. 
Tuesday's morning tide is at 01:30 and at 03:33. Storm Bram increases tide table values by 0.44 m. Total forecast tide is 3.74 metres Chart Datum (1.76 mAOD) at Lymington. Strong Southerly Force 5 wind. Tuesday's afternoon tide is at 13:34 and at 15:31 on 09/12/2025 is forecast to be 7 cm higher (1.83 mAOD). Strong Southerly Force 7 wind. Small amounts of water will flood the footpath near the Ship Inn pub at Town Quay. Saltgrass Lane will flood and be completely impassable to traffic. Property flooding is not expected. 
We are closing flood gates . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides, strong winds and large waves are expected to cause flooding tomorrow morning. 
Flooding is expected from 07:00 am to 11:00 am on 09 December 2025. 
Areas most at risk include properties situated behind East Beach, including Pier Terrace,  Waterside, The Bay House, The Old Watch House, Bridport Arms Hotel, Seagulls, Swains Row, The Old Timber Yard, Station Road, Station Way and George Street.  The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at West Bay of 2.39 mAODN at 9:00AM, which is 0.49m above tide tables, with Southerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)  After this tide the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and deploying flood barriers. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded and activate any flood protection products you may have.

Tuesday morning's high tide is at 02:09 on 09/12/2025. Storm Bram increases tide table values by 0.38 m. The total forecast tide is 5.08 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Strong Southerly Force 5 wind. Tuesday's afternoon tide is at 14:09 on 09/12/2025, and is forecast to be 2 cm lower (2.33 mAOD). Strong Southerly Force 6 wind. It is possible there will be water in the prom at high tide in the Eastoke Corner area. Local teams are monitoring the beach condition at Eastoke for any further actions. 
We are closely monitoring the situation .

items.description: River Yeo and Parrett, Yeovilton to Huish Episcopi
items.message: Levels remain high on the River Yeo following the rain over the weekend. While levels have dropped further up in the Pen Mill and Ilchester areas, river and drain levels are still high in the lowland areas around Long Load and Huish Episcopi. Floodwater remains in the Moors, such as around Long Load, Wet Moor and Huish Episcopi. A band of heavy persistent rain is forecast from this evening, Monday 08 December 2025, through to about midday tomorrow, which will cause further flooding impacts and sustain this Alert. This will cause rivers in the upper catchments to rise again and bring fresh flows down the River Yeo and into the Moors. Drier weather is forecast on Wednesday and Thursday. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. We are checking defences, bridges, culverts and screens. We will pump when river levels allow. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Act on your flood plan if you haven't already. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dart from Dartmeet to Buckfastleigh
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding this morning.

Flooding is expected on 09 December 2025. 

Heavy rain falling in the area will continue throughout the day. 

Properties and low lying areas will start to flood from around 04:30AM on Tuesday. The main areas of concern are Butterflies & Otter Sanctuary, Dart Mills and properties around Dart Bridge at Buckfastleigh. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. 

River levels are forecast to be at their highest between 04:30AM and 08:00AM.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Activate any flood protection products you may have.

This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 09 December 2025 or as the situation changes.
